G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 4, because the amount in controversy exceeds $25,000, exclusive of interest and costs.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 2, and 8.proposition: Venue is proper in Middlesex Superior Court, Lowell Division, pursuant to G.L. c. 223, §§ 1, 2, and 8, because the cause of action arose in Middlesex County, Massachusetts, and the Store where the incident occurred is located in Lowell, Middlesex County.

*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693 (1973.proposition: Plaintiff was a lawful business invitee on the premises, to whom Defendant owed a duty to exercise reasonable care in the ownership, operation, and maintenance of the Store, and to keep the premises in a reasonably safe condition.
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693 (1973.support_reasoning: The quoted portion of Mounsey v. Ellard is a concurring opinion discussing the abandonment of rigid invitee/licensee classifications and critiquing the continued separate treatment of trespassers. It does not state that the plaintiff was a lawful business invitee, nor that a specific ‘business invitee’ duty applied; rather, the case generally moves away from such status-based distinctions. Therefore, it does not support the specific proposition that plaintiff was a business invitee to whom defendant owed the traditional invitee duty to keep the premises reasonably safe.
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693 (1973.relevant_excerpt: “The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a ‘licensee’ rather than an ‘invitee,’ or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors.”

*Davis v. Westwood Group*, 420 Mass. 739.proposition: Plaintiff was a lawful business invitee on the premises, to whom Defendant owed a duty to exercise reasonable care in the ownership, operation, and maintenance of the Store, and to keep the premises in a reasonably safe condition.
*Davis v. Westwood Group*, 420 Mass. 739.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely states the general Massachusetts rule that an owner or possessor of land owes a common-law duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors, including to maintain the premises in reasonably safe condition and to warn of unreasonable dangers. While the court ultimately finds no duty to alter the adjacent state highway, it clearly affirms the general duty described in the proposition toward lawful visitors/business invitees on the premises.
*Davis v. Westwood Group*, 420 Mass. 739.relevant_excerpt: “It is well established that an owner or possessor of land owes a common law duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors. Sullivan v. Brookline, 416 Mass. 825, 827 (1994), citing Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1973). This duty includes an obligation to maintain the premises in reasonably safe condition and to warn visitors of any unreasonable dangers of which the landowner is aware or reasonably should be aware.”

*Dos Santos v. Coleta*, 465 Mass. 148 (2.proposition: Defendant, as the owner and operator of the Store, owed a duty to maintain the premises in a reasonably safe condition for invitees, including Plaintiff, and to protect them against reasonably foreseeable risks of harm.
*Dos Santos v. Coleta*, 465 Mass. 148 (2.support_reasoning: The case discusses a landowner/possessor of land’s duty to lawful entrants, not a commercial store’s duty to invitees. While it affirms that an owner or possessor of land owes a duty of reasonable care to maintain the property in a reasonably safe condition and to protect lawful visitors from foreseeable harm, the factual and doctrinal context is residential premises, not a retail store. Thus, it supports a general premises-liability duty, but not specifically the duty of a store owner/operator as framed in the proposition.
*Dos Santos v. Coleta*, 465 Mass. 148 (2.relevant_excerpt: “An owner or possessor of land owes a common-law duty of reasonable care to all persons lawfully on the premises. … This duty includes an obligation to maintain the ‘property in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk.’ … It also includes an obligation ‘to warn visitors of any unreasonable dangers of which the landowner is aware or reasonably should be aware.’”

*Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co.*, 400 M.proposition: Defendant also owed a duty to inspect, stock, and arrange merchandise in a manner that did not create an unreasonable risk of injury to customers lawfully on the premises.
*Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co.*, 400 M.support_reasoning: The quoted concurring opinion does not discuss any duty to inspect, stock, or arrange merchandise; it concerns only whether the gasoline station operator had a duty to warn customers about the obvious risk of negligent operation of other vehicles. Justice Wilkins expressly concludes there is no duty to warn of that inherent and obvious danger. Nothing in this passage establishes or affirms a broader duty regarding arrangement or stocking of merchandise to avoid unreasonable risks of injury.
*Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co.*, 400 M.relevant_excerpt: “In my view, the risk of injury to a customer from the negligent operation of another vehicle on the premises of a self-service station is inherent and obvious. There is no duty to warn of such a danger.”

*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.raw_text: *Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth.*, 363 Mass. 165 (1973)
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.proposition: Defendant also owed a duty to inspect, stock, and arrange merchandise in a manner that did not create an unreasonable risk of injury to customers lawfully on the premises.
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.case_name: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.support_reasoning: The case involves a slip-and-fall on a stairway in a subway station, not merchandise, and the court frames the duty in general premises-liability terms: to use due care to keep premises reasonably safe or warn of hidden dangers. It does not discuss any specific duty to inspect, stock, or arrange merchandise, nor any analogous duty about how goods are displayed. Thus it supports only a general duty to maintain safe premises, not the more specific merchandise-related duty stated in the proposition.
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.relevant_excerpt: “The obligation of one who controls business premises is to use due care to keep the premises provided for the use of its patrons in a reasonably safe condition, or at least to warn them of any dangers that might arise from such use, which are not likely to be known to them, and of which the defendant knows or ought to know.”

*Sharpe v. Peter Pan Bus Lines, Inc.*, 4.raw_text: *Sharpe v. Peter Pan Bus Lines, Inc.*, 401 Mass. 788 (1988)
*Sharpe v. Peter Pan Bus Lines, Inc.*, 4.proposition: Defendant knew or should have known that ordinary customer conduct—such as pushing a cart and having it occasionally bump a shelf—was foreseeable and should have been anticipated and guarded against.
*Sharpe v. Peter Pan Bus Lines, Inc.*, 4.case_name: Sharpe v. Peter Pan Bus Lines, Inc.
*Sharpe v. Peter Pan Bus Lines, Inc.*, 4.support_reasoning: The case concerns a bus terminal’s duty to protect patrons from criminal assaults by third parties and the foreseeability of violent crime given prior incidents and neighborhood conditions. It does not address ordinary customer conduct like pushing a cart or incidental contact with fixtures, nor does it discuss the foreseeability of such benign, everyday conduct or a duty to guard against it. Using this opinion to support a proposition about foreseeability of routine customer bumping would mischaracterize its holding and context.
*Sharpe v. Peter Pan Bus Lines, Inc.*, 4.relevant_excerpt: "There was evidence warranting a finding that the stabbing of Sharon was within the reasonably foreseeable risks created by each defendant’s breach of duty. The jury could have reasonably found that the defendants were negligent in failing to provide a uniformed security force in the terminal. … The presence of uniformed police or security personnel provides a deterrent effect. … The jury could reasonably have concluded that as a deterrent to crime the defendants had a duty to provide uniformed security personnel in the terminal at the time of the attack."

*Gallagher v. Stop & Shop, Inc.*, 332 Ma.proposition: Defendant either created the hazardous condition by the manner in which it stacked and displayed its merchandise, or allowed the hazardous condition to exist for such a length of time that, in the exercise of reasonable care, it should have discovered and corrected it.
*Gallagher v. Stop & Shop, Inc.*, 332 Ma.support_reasoning: The case clearly addresses only one theory of liability: that the defendant allowed a foreign substance (melted ice cream) to remain on the floor for a sufficient time that, in the exercise of reasonable care, it should have discovered and removed it. The opinion expressly states there was no evidence the defendant or its employees created the condition, and plaintiff’s specifications limited the theory to constructive notice, not negligent creation by stacking or display of merchandise. Thus, it supports only the ‘length of time/constructive notice’ portion, not the ‘created the hazardous condition by stacking and displaying merchandise’ portion of the proposition as written.
*Gallagher v. Stop & Shop, Inc.*, 332 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “There is no evidence that the ice cream was there through the acts of any persons for whose conduct the defendant was responsible… Likewise there was no evidence that the defendant or any of its employees knew of the presence of this ice cream… The plaintiff’s right to recover therefore depends upon evidence from which the jury could find that the defendant, in the exercise of reasonable care, should have known of and removed this foreign substance.”

*Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co.*, 3.raw_text: *Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co.*, 343 Mass. 263 (1961)
*Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co.*, 3.proposition: Defendant either created the hazardous condition by the manner in which it stacked and displayed its merchandise, or allowed the hazardous condition to exist for such a length of time that, in the exercise of reasonable care, it should have discovered and corrected it.
*Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co.*, 3.case_name: Deagle v. Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Co.
*Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co.*, 3.support_reasoning: The case discusses both theories—creation of the hazard and constructive notice—but holds that there was no evidence the defendant created the hazardous condition by how it stacked or displayed merchandise, and no evidence that the oil had been on the floor long enough to charge the defendant with constructive notice. The opinion therefore rejects, rather than affirms, the proposition that these bases for liability were satisfied on the facts. It is useful as a statement of the governing standards, but not as authority that the defendant did create the condition or had sufficient time to discover it.
*Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co.*, 3.relevant_excerpt: “There was no evidence… that the dangerous condition was caused by a person for whose conduct the defendant was responsible or that the defendant’s employees knew of the condition. In this state of the case it was incumbent upon the plaintiff to show that the oil had been on the floor for such a length of time that the defendant’s employees, in the exercise of reasonable care, should have been aware of its presence… There was no direct evidence here as to when the bottle of pine oil was broken.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: Defendant owed Plaintiff, as a business invitee, a duty to exercise reasonable care in the ownership, operation, maintenance, and control of the Store, including the duty to keep the premises in a reasonably safe condition and to protect against foreseeable harms.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 60F.proposition: Plaintiff’s injuries and damages are compensable under Massachusetts law, including but not limited to G.L. c. 231, § 85 (comparative negligence); G.L. c. 231, § 60F (prejudgment interest in tort actions); and the common law of negligence.

*Whittaker v. Saraceno*, 418 Mass. 196 (.proposition: The risk that a customer or shopping cart might lightly bump a shelf in a busy retail store is foreseeable as a matter of law and common experience, and Defendant’s duty of reasonable care includes taking precautions against such foreseeable conduct.
*Whittaker v. Saraceno*, 418 Mass. 196 (.support_reasoning: The case concerns a commercial landlord’s duty to protect against criminal assaults in an office building and turns on whether such violent criminal acts were reasonably foreseeable. It does not involve retail store operations, customers, shopping carts, or the foreseeability of minor bumping of shelves, nor does it articulate any rule that such minor contact is foreseeable as a matter of law. The opinion instead limits duty by requiring proof that the landowner knew or should have known of a threat of criminal violence, which is a different context and principle than the proposition claimed.
*Whittaker v. Saraceno*, 418 Mass. 196 (.relevant_excerpt: “The possibility of criminal conduct occurring is present in almost every aspect of daily life. In that sense the possibility of a violent attack is always able to be foreseen. However, society should not place the burden of all harm caused by random violent criminal conduct on the owner of the property where the harmful act occurred, without proof that the landowner knew or had reason to know of a threat to the safety of persons lawfully on the premises against which the landowner could have taken reasonable preventive steps.”

*Aylward v. McCloskey*, 412 Mass. 77 (19.proposition: Defendant either created the dangerous condition through its own merchandising practices or allowed it to remain uncorrected despite having actual or constructive notice of the hazard.
*Aylward v. McCloskey*, 412 Mass. 77 (19.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns liability where a defendant creates a dangerous condition through its merchandising practices or fails to correct it despite notice—essentially a premises-liability / hazard-creation or notice theory, typically in a retail context. Aylward v. McCloskey instead addresses residential landowner liability for natural accumulations of snow and ice and holds that, absent evidence that the landowner created a defect or had negligence beyond the mere natural accumulation, there is no liability. The case does not discuss merchandising practices, nor does it impose a duty to remedy naturally occurring conditions absent some act altering them; it therefore does not support the stated proposition and in fact is largely contrary to it.
*Aylward v. McCloskey*, 412 Mass. 77 (19.relevant_excerpt: “We do not suggest that an accumulation of snow and ice on one’s property can never be a hazardous or defective condition which the owner or occupier has a legal responsibility to remedy. To be sure, in circumstances where some act or failure to act has changed the condition of naturally accumulated snow and ice, and the elements alone or in connection with the land become a hazard to lawful visitors, then a defect may exist, creating liability in the owner or occupier.… In the present case, there is no contention that any defect existed on the property, beyond the mere presence of naturally accumulated snow and ice.”

*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a possessor of land is liable when its failure to exercise reasonable care to protect invitees from dangers on the land results in foreseeable harm.
*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states that Massachusetts premises liability law imposes on property owners a duty to use reasonable care to keep property reasonably safe for lawful visitors, and it applies that same duty to snow and ice conditions. The court abolishes the natural/unnatural accumulation distinction and reaffirms that if a property owner knows or should know of a dangerous condition on the land, it must take reasonable steps to protect lawful visitors from foreseeable harm. This directly matches the proposition that possessors of land are liable when their failure to exercise reasonable care to protect invitees from dangers on the land results in foreseeable harm.
*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “We now will apply to hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation that a property owner owes to lawful visitors as to all other hazards: a duty to ‘act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances including the likelihood of injury to others, the probable seriousness of such injuries, and the burden of reducing or avoiding the risk.’… If a property owner knows or reasonably should know of a dangerous condition on its property… the property owner owes a duty to lawful visitors to make reasonable efforts to protect lawful visitors against the danger.”

*Rodrigues v. Miriam Hosp.*, 160 F.3d 26.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to recover all damages proximately caused by Defendant’s negligence, including but not limited to medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, and loss of enjoyment of life.
*Rodrigues v. Miriam Hosp.*, 160 F.3d 26.case_name: Cadbury Beverages, Inc. v. National Labor Relations Board
*Rodrigues v. Miriam Hosp.*, 160 F.3d 26.support_reasoning: The opinion is an NLRA/unfair labor practice case focused on whether an employer unlawfully suspended and terminated an employee for protected concerted activity. It does not address tort damages, personal injury, or any rule about a plaintiff’s entitlement to recover categories of damages such as medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, or loss of enjoyment of life. Therefore it cannot be cited as authority for the stated damages proposition.
*Rodrigues v. Miriam Hosp.*, 160 F.3d 26.relevant_excerpt: For the foregoing reasons, we deny the petition for review and grant the cross-application for enforcement of the Board’s order.

*Santos v. Chrysler Corp.*, 430 Mass. 19.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to recover all damages proximately caused by Defendant’s negligence, including but not limited to medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, and loss of enjoyment of life.
*Santos v. Chrysler Corp.*, 430 Mass. 19.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses liability, evidentiary issues, wrongful death, comparative negligence, and indemnity, but it does not articulate any general rule that a plaintiff is entitled to recover all damages proximately caused by the defendant’s negligence, nor does it enumerate categories such as medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, or loss of enjoyment of life. The damages portion simply reports the jury’s verdict amounts in this specific case without framing a general legal principle about recoverable elements of damages. Therefore, it does not serve as authority for the broad damages proposition stated.
*Santos v. Chrysler Corp.*, 430 Mass. 19.relevant_excerpt: “The jury awarded $12.8 million in compensatory damages for the wrongful deaths of the wife and children, the conscious pain and suffering of the wife, the wife’s lost future earnings, and the plaintiff’s personal injuries. The jury also awarded $15,705 in punitive damages.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Pre-judgment and post-judgment interest as allowed by law, including pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B and/or § 6C;

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6C.proposition: Pre-judgment and post-judgment interest as allowed by law, including pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B and/or § 6C;

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 60.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 60, Plaintiff hereby demands a trial by jury on all issues so triable.
